S3.T1.caption: Table 1: Comparison of secure union protocols for the proposed secure aggregation.

Protocol Communication Cost (bits) Clients Learn (besides V𝑉V) Servers Learn

references:
Now, we will define a set of protocols,
each with a different secure perimeter and communication cost trade-off (see Table 1),
for finding the union of indices.
In each protocol, each client i𝑖i has a list of indices Visubscript𝑉𝑖V_{i} whose components
belong to [1,N]1𝑁[1,N].
The clients would like to securely evaluate the union
of the lists of indices V=⋃i=1CVi𝑉superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐶subscript𝑉𝑖V=\bigcup_{i=1}^{C}V_{i}.

S3.T2.caption:
Table 2: Communication costs per federated round for the different protocols
where |V|𝑉|V| is the size of the union of indices,
for Bonawitz et al. (2017), aK=aS=256subscript𝑎𝐾subscript𝑎𝑆256a_{K}=a_{S}=256 are the number of bits in a public key and in an encrypted share,
all operations are evaluated in ℤTsubscriptℤ𝑇\mathbb{Z}_{T} with T=232𝑇superscript232T=2^{32},
for Dong et al. (2020), p​r​e​c=24𝑝𝑟𝑒𝑐24prec=24 and p​a​d=8𝑝𝑎𝑑8pad=8 are HE parameters used to avoid overflows.
references:
In this section, we estimate the total communication cost per federated round of
FedAvg without secure aggregation
and of our proposed method with secure aggregation,
as summarized in Table 2.
We choose a 32-bit floating-point representation for all “unquantized” real values.

In our proposed method, we adapt a compressed FL learning strategy to be more amenable to secure computation
in order to obtain a secure aggregation which has a lower communication and computation costs than reported in Bonawitz et al. (2017); Dong et al. (2020).
Table 2 summarizes the communication costs of the secure aggregations from
Bonawitz et al. (2017); Dong et al. (2020).

Finally, we analytically estimate
the communication costs associated with these strategies
(see Table 2),
the results of which are detailed in Table 3.
These experimental results showcase the low total communication cost of our
proposed compressed secure aggregation approach compared to other
techniques with or without secure aggregation.
This communication cost can be further reduced with more fine tuning, as
higher compression rates (i.e. ρ<0.02𝜌0.02\rho<0.02) may be achievable for the
same performance level Sattler et al. (2018).

to reach the targeted accuracy with FedAvg strategy
and our approach on five clients.

references:
To compare the computation cost, we compare the cost of the most expensive operations.
For non secure aggregations and our proposed methods,
only additions (noted ”+” in Table 3) are performed.
Dong et al. (2020) with TSS is based on polynomial interpolation (noted ”++” in Table 3)
which is more expensive than additions.
Dong et al. (2020) with HE and Bonawitz et al. (2017) are based on the most expensive operations
respectively Paillier HE and asymmetric encryption (noted ”+++” in Table 3).

Finally, we analytically estimate
the communication costs associated with these strategies
(see Table 2),
the results of which are detailed in Table 3.
These experimental results showcase the low total communication cost of our
proposed compressed secure aggregation approach compared to other
techniques with or without secure aggregation.
This communication cost can be further reduced with more fine tuning, as
higher compression rates (i.e. ρ<0.02𝜌0.02\rho<0.02) may be achievable for the
same performance level Sattler et al. (2018).

When using the SecUnion protocol,
false negatives occur only when at least 2 clients have selected the same index x𝑥x
and ∑i=1CAi​[x]mod2qmodulosuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐶subscript𝐴𝑖delimited-[]𝑥superscript2𝑞\sum_{i=1}^{C}A_{i}[x]\mod 2^{q} is equal to zero.
The probability that at least 2 clients have selected the same index x𝑥x is equal to
Pr​[t≥2|N,k,C]=1−P​(N,k,C,0)−P​(N,k,C,1)Prdelimited-[]𝑡conditional2𝑁𝑘𝐶1𝑃𝑁𝑘𝐶0𝑃𝑁𝑘𝐶1\text{Pr}[t\geq 2|N,k,C]=1-P(N,k,C,0)-P(N,k,C,1).
When one index is selected by at least 2 clients, the probability to obtain a false negative
for this index is equal to 1/2q1superscript2𝑞1/2^{q}.
Thus, the expected number of false negatives in V𝑉V is given by
N×P​[t≥2|N,k,C]×12q𝑁𝑃delimited-[]𝑡conditional2𝑁𝑘𝐶1superscript2𝑞N\times P[t\geq 2|N,k,C]\times\frac{1}{2^{q}}.
The Table 4 presents the average amount of false negatives in the SecUnion protocol for different parameters.

Let us assume the client i𝑖i observes that A​[x]=Ri,x𝐴delimited-[]𝑥subscript𝑅𝑖𝑥A[x]=R_{i,x} for one index x𝑥x.
The client i𝑖i is not alone to have selected this index x𝑥x, when at least two other
clients have selected this index x𝑥x and the sum of the random values
Ri,xsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑥R_{i,x} selected by these other clients is equal to 00 in ℤ2qsubscriptℤsuperscript2𝑞\mathbb{Z}_{2^{q}}.
The probability that at least two other clients have selected this index x𝑥x
is equal to Pr​[t≥2|N,k,C−1]Prdelimited-[]𝑡conditional2𝑁𝑘𝐶1\text{Pr}[t\geq 2|N,k,C-1].
When several clients have selected this index x𝑥x,
the sum of their random values Ri,xsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑥R_{i,x} will be equal to 00 with probability 1/2q1superscript2𝑞1/2^{q}.
Finally, if one client i𝑖i observes that A​[x]=Ri,x𝐴delimited-[]𝑥subscript𝑅𝑖𝑥A[x]=R_{i,x}, then the client can
infer he alone has selected this index x𝑥x, with probability 1−12q​Pr​[t≥2|N,k,C−1]11superscript2𝑞Prdelimited-[]𝑡conditional2𝑁𝑘𝐶11-\frac{1}{2^{q}}~{}\text{Pr}[t\geq 2|N,k,C-1].
This probability is evaluated for some parameters in Table 5.

references:
For our MNIST experiments, we train a simple LeNet-5 network Lecun et al. (1998)
which consists of N=61,706𝑁61706N=61,706 trainable parameters.
This architecture is detailed in Table 6 in Appendix D.
For CIFAR-10, we train the same AlexNet Krizhevsky et al. (2017) architecture as demonstrated in the original
FedAvg work McMahan et al. (2017),
which consists of N=1,756,426𝑁1756426N=1,756,426 trainable parameters.
This architecture is detailed in Table 7 in Appendix D.
We also utilize the same image preprocessing
pipeline as was proposed in this work, e.g. random flipping, and color normalization.

In this appendix, we present the LeNet architecture used for experiments on MNIST (see Table 6)
and the AlexNet architecture used for experiments on CIFAR-10
(see Table 7).
